The traditionally accepted explanation for the activity of Kampo medicines ‐ including Hozai —was summarized in the 18th century CE by the philosopher Yoshimasu Todo (1702–1773), who stated that curative and toxic effects are two phases of the same process; since diseases are triggered by uncontrolled poisoning, the patient has to be healed by a positive, challenging poisoning. This controlled poisoning initiates a regeneration reaction that removes toxicity from the body, thus restoring the patient's health.
94 In this context, hozai and adaptogens are similar since adaptogens are eustressors (i.e., good stressors) acting as mild stress mimetics or stress‐vaccines that induce a stress‐protective response,
